prompt: What rule allows us to derive P from (P ∧ Q)?
hint: We're extracting one part from a conjunction.
explanation: Simplification (Simp): From (P ∧ Q), derive P (or Q). If both P and Q are true, then certainly P alone is true. We can 'simplify' by dropping one conjunct.
visual_concept: A bag contains an apple AND an orange. You can certainly pull out just the apple.
